pageProps.contentHtml:
Riemann mapping theorem, Schwarz lemma

Let Ω⊆C\Omega \subseteq \CΩ⊆C be a simply connected domain with Ω≠C\Omega \neq \CΩ=C, and f ⁣:Ω→Ω\func{f}{\Omega}{\Omega}f:Ω→Ω be a holomorphic mapping. Suppose that there exist points z1,z2∈Ωz_1, z_2 \in \Omegaz1​,z2​∈Ω, z1≠z2z_1 \neq z_2z1​=z2​, with f(z1)=z1f\p{z_1} = z_1f(z1​)=z1​ and f(z2)=z2f\p{z_2} = z_2f(z2​)=z2​. Show that fff is the identity on Ω\OmegaΩ, i.e., f(z)=zf\p{z} = zf(z)=z for all z∈Ωz \in \Omegaz∈Ω.
Solution.

By the Riemann mapping theorem, there exists a conformal map φ ⁣:Ω→D\func{\phi}{\Omega}{\D}φ:Ω→D. Hence, g=φ∘f∘φ−1 ⁣:D→D\func{g = \phi \circ f \circ \phi^{-1}}{\D}{\D}g=φ∘f∘φ−1:D→D is a holomorphic map. Thus,

g(φ(zj))=φ(f(zj))=φ(zj)g\p{\phi\p{z_j}} = \phi\p{f\p{z_j}} = \phi\p{z_j}g(φ(zj​))=φ(f(zj​))=φ(zj​)

for j=1,2j = 1, 2j=1,2. For a∈Da \in \Da∈D, consider the Blaschke factor ψa ⁣:D→D\func{\psi_a}{\D}{\D}ψa​:D→D given by

ψa(z)=z−a1−a‾z,\psi_a\p{z} = \frac{z - a}{1 - \conj{a}z},ψa​(z)=1−azz−a​,

which is an automorphism of the disk that maps aaa to 000. Consider h=ψφ(z1)∘g∘ψφ(z1)−1 ⁣:D→D\func{h = \psi_{\phi\p{z_1}} \circ g \circ \psi_{\phi\p{z_1}}^{-1}}{\D}{\D}h=ψφ(z1​)​∘g∘ψφ(z1​)−1​:D→D, and notice that

h(0)=(ψφ(z1)∘g)(φ(z1))=ψφ(z1)(φ(z1))=0.h\p{0} = \p{\psi_{\phi\p{z_1}} \circ g}\p{\phi\p{z_1}} = \psi_{\phi\p{z_1}}\p{\phi\p{z_1}} = 0.h(0)=(ψφ(z1​)​∘g)(φ(z1​))=ψφ(z1​)​(φ(z1​))=0.

Moreover,

h(ψφ(z1)(φ(z2)))=(ψφ(z1)∘g)(φ(z2))=ψφ(z1)(φ(z2)),h\p{\psi_{\phi\p{z_1}}\p{\phi\p{z_2}}} = \p{\psi_{\phi\p{z_1}} \circ g}\p{\phi\p{z_2}} = \psi_{\phi\p{z_1}}\p{\phi\p{z_2}},h(ψφ(z1​)​(φ(z2​)))=(ψφ(z1​)​∘g)(φ(z2​))=ψφ(z1​)​(φ(z2​)),

so ψφ(z1)(φ(z2))\psi_{\phi\p{z_1}}\p{\phi\p{z_2}}ψφ(z1​)​(φ(z2​)) is a fixed point of hhh. By the Schwarz lemma, this implies that hhh is the identity, and so

id⁡=h=ψφ(z1)∘g∘ψφ(z1)−1  ⟹  g=id⁡.\id = h = \psi_{\phi\p{z_1}} \circ g \circ \psi_{\phi\p{z_1}}^{-1} \implies g = \id.id=h=ψφ(z1​)​∘g∘ψφ(z1​)−1​⟹g=id.

Similarly,

id⁡=g=φ∘f∘φ−1  ⟹  f=id⁡,\id = g = \phi \circ f \circ \phi^{-1} \implies f = \id,id=g=φ∘f∘φ−1⟹f=id,

which completes the proof.
